newsitem.title: MEXICO: Banco de Mexico net reserves rise, assets fall.
newsitem.headline: Banco de Mexico net reserves rise, assets fall.

text.p: Banco de Mexico said on Tuesday its international reserves as of July 25 were $22.512 billion, compared to $22.474 billion on July 18.
The central bank said that its net international assets as of the same date were $15.184 billion compared to $15.196 billion the week before.
The central bank said the decrease of $13 million in net international assets during the period was due to:
--Net outflows from operations with state oil company Pemex worth $56 million.
--Net outflows of foreign currency from operations with the federal government worth $31 million.

--A net gain of $74 million for a combination of factors including changes in the dollar value of non-dollar assets and liabilities held by the bank; net returns on interest rates and from trading of metals and securities; and net deposits in dollar accounts from commercial banks at the central bank.
It said that as of July 25, the foreign currency fund aimed at a prepayment of bank notes on August 6 was $5.982 billion.
Banco de Mexico said that between April 18 and April 25 the monetary base fell 2.439 billion pesos due to a fall in the seasonal demand of bills and coins.
In the same period, the government's balance at the central bank rose 14.848 billion pesos, due mainly to tax collection.

The bank said it undertook monetary regulation operations for a total of 10.846 billion pesos in the same time frame in order to meet a greater demand for bills and coins as well as to offset the increase in federal government deposits in the account it holds with the central bank.
The following tables detail Banco de Mexico's reserves and net domestic credit. All figures are in billions of pesos, unless otherwise indicated.
July 18 July 25
International Reserves
U.S. Dollars $22.474 bln $22.512 bln
Monetary Base 83.348 80.909
Net International Assets*
U.S. Dollars $15.196 bln $15.184 bln
Net Domestic Credit -36.854 -37.099
*Net International Assets are defined as gross international assets minus central bank liabilities with the IMF and assets of less than a six-month duration from other central banks.
